results.title: Christina Stead
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
In the only filmed interview with one of Australia’s most popular and respected novelists, Christina Stead is both challenging and revealing.

group.title: Australia Council archival film series: writers I

results.title: Marjorie Barnard
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
Historical novelist, Marjorie Barnard recalls priceless memories of fellow writers who “peopled her world”, including Xavier Herbert, Vance and Nettie Palmer and Frank Dalby Davison.

group.title: Australia Council archival film series: writers I

results.title: A.D. Hope
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
A D Hope talks in this entertaining interview of his childhood and its influence on his poetry, and the conflict with his life as a critic and academic.

results.title: Kylie Tennant
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
Kylie Tennant drew her inspiration from people she knew, and her exuberant interview is in itself a valuable piece of Australian social history.

group.title: Australia Council archival film series: writers I

results.title: Douglas Stewart
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
Playwright and poet, Douglas Stewart, was for many years the Literary Editor of the Bulletin, and friend of many writers and artists, including Norman Lindsay, Judith Wright and David Campbell.

results.title: John Blight
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
An insightful and humorous conversation with the renowned Queensland poet brimming with anecdotes about the Depression and the development of his poetry.

group.title: Australia Council archival film series: writers I

results.title: Judith Wright
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
As well as being one of Australia’s more eminent poets and novelists, Judith Wright is an outspoken commentator on conservation and Aboriginal land rights.

results.title: Rock-a-bye baby
results.creator_credit: L. Richard Ellison, National Educational Television and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World We Live In”.
Examines some of the techniques psychologists use to assess mothering practices with young infants. Stresses the importance of touch and movement in young children. Examples of monkeys in isolation, children in orphanages, and premature infants are used to show the effects of various maternal deprivations. Narrated by Dan Ingram. NB: CONTAINS SOME DISTURBING IMAGES WITH MONKEYS.
results.creator_credit_for_label: L. Richard Ellison, National Educational Television and Time-Life Films

group_siblings.title: The Dam builders: beavers and man

results.title: The Dam builders: beavers and man
results.creator_credit: L. Richard Ellison, National Educational Television and Time-Life Broadcast
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World We Live In”.
A comparison of the ecological changes brought about by the dam building activities of two species of mammals - humans and the beaver. It shows that all life is interdependent and points out how humans are damaging the ecological balance of nature whereas the beaver, although bringing change to its area, is not. Shows beavers in north America and engineers in Africa. Narrated by Joseph Julian.
results.creator_credit_for_label: L. Richard Ellison, National Educational Television and Time-Life Broadcast
